thinking.disposable_income: High disposable income with median household income of $121,562 and 58.8% of households making over $100,000. This suggests residents can generally absorb higher transportation costs and taxes
thinking.discretionary_consumption: High discretionary spending capacity given the affluent population. The 1.5% tax would impact larger purchases but is manageable for most residents given their income levels
thinking.accessibility: Excellent multi-modal accessibility with 45.6% no-car households, high transit usage (18.9%), and significant walk/bike share (27.6%). Area has good transit infrastructure and many residents rely on non-car transportation
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Given high income levels, prioritized policies that improve transit service and reduce congestion even if costs are higher. 2. Large car-free population benefits from better transit service. 3. High walking/biking share suggests support for policies reducing car traffic. 4. Selected policies balancing higher driver fees (to reduce congestion) with moderate-to-higher transit fares (as affordability less critical). 5. Higher tax rates acceptable given income levels and benefits of improved service
